questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. On examination, his GCS was E2M2V3. He had no fractures and no hydrocephalus or raised intracranial pressure. Non-contrast CT was performed and was found to be normal. The likely diagnosis is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A Diffuse axonal injury

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of the patient who had an RTA presents with an abnormal clinical manifestation and no imaging abnormality suggests diffuse axonal injury.

 

C/F: High energy trauma (road traffic accident) + Low GCS score / comatose

Initial investigation for DAI→ NCCT: Normal or tiny microbleeds

IOC for DAI → MRI

Sequence of MRI best: SWI/ Gradient MR: Shows blooming suggestive of axonal shearing

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Post-concussion syndrome: Patients with post-concussion syndrome have mild traumatic brain injury. It does not present with a severe clinical status as seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Extra Dural hemorrhage: Extradural hemorrhage results secondary to trauma to head. The bleeding is usually arterial and blood collects between outer dura and inner table of the skull. It can very well be visualized on CT.

 

Option D. Post-concussion syndrome: A cerebral herniation is a shift of cerebral tissue in an adjacent space. Intracranial brain herniation can be classified into 3 types - subfalcine, trans tentorial and tonsillar. A distinct clinical picture can be produced as a result of compression of neurovascular structures by the herniating part. CT is the imaging modality of choice because it can be done rapidly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of road traffic accidents where a patient presents with a significant neurological deficit and a normal initial CT scan, diffuse axonal injury should be considered. An MRI with specific sequences is required to confirm the diagnosis and understand the extent of injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option in Guillain Barre syndrome? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steroids

 

Steroids are not effective in the treatment of Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) and do not improve outcomes. This has been confirmed by multiple studies and clinical trials, leading to their non-recommendation in GBS management protocols.

 

While steroids have no role in acute GBS treatment, they are used in managing Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP), which is a related condition that requires long-term immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin): IVIG is a widely accepted treatment for GBS, where it is used to modulate the immune response. The typical regimen involves a total dose of 2 g/kg given over 2-5 days. IVIG is believed to neutralize circulating antibodies and reduce inflammation, leading to a decrease in the severity and duration of the disease.

 

Option C. Plasmapheresis: Also known as plasma exchange, plasmapheresis is used in GBS to remove harmful antibodies from the blood. This treatment is particularly useful in severe cases and is often started within the first two weeks of symptom onset for maximum effectiveness.

 

Option D. Ventilator support: Because GBS can lead to paralysis of the muscles used for breathing, ventilator support may be necessary for patients with severe respiratory muscle weakness. This supportive care is crucial in managing life-threatening complications of GBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Steroids are not recommended for treating Guillain-Barre Syndrome due to their lack of efficacy in this specific condition, while IVIG and plasmapheresis are effective treatments. Supportive care, such as ventilator support, plays a vital role in managing severe cases where respiratory muscles are compromised.

 

Reference - Harrison neurology, Immune mediated neuropathies/GBS/Chap 447/12730

questions.text: Mw vaccine is extracted from which of the following bacteria? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) M. indicus pranii

 

Mw vaccine is extracted from M. indicus pranii

 

The Mycobacterium w (M.w) vaccine is a heat-killed suspension derived from a non-pathogenic mycobacterium: mycobacterium indicus pranii. As an immunotherapy, M.w is used against leprosy; the compound also shares antigens with M. tuberculosis. Its use has shown clinical improvement, rapid bacterial clearance, and enhanced immune responses to Mycobacterium leprae antigens.

 

Administration: 0.1 ml intradermal. It is divided into two equal doses and given on both arms. Booster doses are injected only on one arm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M. welchii: This bacterium is known for causing gas gangrene and is not associated with the Mw vaccine.

 

Option C. M. leprae: This bacterium is the causative agent of leprosy, but the Mw vaccine is not derived from M. leprae itself.

 

Option D. M. bovis: This bacterium causes tuberculosis in cattle and can also infect humans, but it is not the source of the Mw vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mw vaccine is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii and is used in the immunotherapy of leprosy, enhancing immune responses and promoting rapid bacterial clearance.

questions.text: Pancreatic cancer has the highest association with: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peutz Jegher’s syndrome

 

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is significantly associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer. PJS is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the development of benign polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and distinctive pigmented spots on the skin. It is caused by mutations in the STK11 (LKB1) gene. Individuals with PJS have a markedly increased risk of developing several types of cancer, including a 36% lifetime risk of developing pancreatic cancer, which is considerably higher compared to the general population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FAMMM Syndrome: While FAMMM (familial atypical multiple mole melanoma) syndrome, associated with mutations in the p16/CDKN2A gene, increases the risk for melanoma and pancreatic cancer, its association with pancreatic cancer is not as strong as that seen in PJS.

 

Option B. FAP (Familial Adenomatous Polyposis): FAP, primarily known for its high risk of colorectal cancer, also has some association with other cancers including pancreatic cancer, but again not as high as PJS.

 

Option C. Hereditary pancreatitis: Typically caused by mutations in the PRSS1 gene, hereditary pancreatitis does increase the risk for pancreatic cancer, but the risk is less compared to PJS.


Educational Objective:

 

Pancreatic cancer has highest association with Peutz Jeghers syndrome.

 

Hereditary risk factors -

 

  • Peutz Jeghers syndrome- STK 11 (LKB1)
  • Hereditary pancreatitis – PRSS1 / SPIN 11
  • Cystic fibrosis – CFTR
  • FAMMM (familial atypical multiple mole melanoma)- p16/ CDKN2A
  • Hereditary breast &ovarian cancer- BRCA2
  • HNPCC/ Lynch syndrome – MLH1, MSH2, MSH 6, PMS2

questions.text: Methyl tetrahydrofolate accumulation and functional deficiency of folate is seen in the deficiency of: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vit B12

 

Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is essential for DNA synthesis and plays a role in the conversion of methyl tetrahydrofolate to its active form. Deficiency of vitamin B12 can lead to the functional deficiency of folate because it impairs the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl tetrahydrofolate, leading to the accumulation of the latter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid: Folic acid, also known as vitamin B9, is a crucial vitamin required for DNA synthesis, cell division, and various metabolic processes. In cases of folic acid deficiency, methyl tetrahydrofolate can accumulate, but there is no direct deficiency of vitamin B12. Folic acid deficiency primarily affects folate-dependent reactions.

 

Option C. Vit B1: Vitamin B1, also known as thiamine, is not directly related to the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate. It primarily plays a role in carbohydrate metabolism as a cofactor for enzymes involved in the citric acid cycle.

 

Option D. Vit B6: Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is involved in various enzymatic reactions, including those related to amino acid metabolism. It is not directly associated with the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the metabolic consequences of vitamin deficiencies, medical students should recognize that the functional deficiency of folate, characterized by the accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate, is primarily seen in vitamin B12 deficiency, making it important to distinguish between the two deficiencies in clinical practice.

 

Deficiency of Vitamin B12 leads to accumulation of methyl THF. Free THF becomes deficient (Folate Trap) and as THF is functional form of folate it is also known as functional deficiency of folate.

 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 536

questions.text: Chimeric DNA is used for? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Organ transplantation

 

Chimeric DNA (also known a recombinant DNA) is used in organ transplantation, especially in bone marrow transplant. It allows for the production of essential therapeutic proteins and other biological products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paternity test:

  • Function: Uses genetic markers to determine biological parentage.
  • Relevance: Typically uses DNA fingerprinting rather than chimeric DNA technology.

 

Option B. Maternity test:

  • Function: Similar to paternity testing, using genetic markers for parentage.
  • Relevance: Uses DNA fingerprinting, not chimeric DNA.

 

Option C. Personal identification:

  • Function: Uses DNA profiling for forensic and legal identification.
  • Relevance: DNA fingerprinting and STR analysis are common methods, not chimeric DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uses of Chimeric DNA are:

 

  1. Recombinant human insulin
  2. Recombinant human growth hormone (HGH, somatotropin) and other human hormones (e.g. FSH)
  3. Recombinant blood clotting factor VIII and other clotting factors (Factor IX, tPA, hirudin)
  4. Recombinant hepatitis B vaccine, HPV vaccine, etc.
  5. Cytokines and growth factors (interferon, interleukins, etc.)
  6. Monoclonal antibodies and other related products (rituximab, trastuzumab, etc.)
  7. Recombinant enzymes (acid α glucosidase [myozyme], α L iduronidase [aldurazyme])
  8. Recombinant HIV protein for HIV ELISA testing
  9. Herbicide and insect resistant crops
  10. Other products: Bone morphogenic protein (BMP), albumin, fibinolytic and thrombolytic agents, etc.
  11. Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in sit hybridization (FISH).
  12. Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  13. Restriction Fragment Length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SN)
  14. Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  15. Gene therapy and bone marrow transplantation

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation for Assertion.
Assertion is true, but Reason is false.
Assertion is false, but Reason is true.

questions.text:
Assertion: Sacubitril/Valsartan is indicated in the treatment of NYHA class II to IV in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

 

Reason: Sacubitril/Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) counteracts RAAS system and raises the level of vasoactive peptaaides.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion.

 

Sacubitril/Valsartan, marketed as Entresto, is a combination medication classified as an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI). It is specifically indicated for the treatment of patients with chronic heart failure classified as NYHA class II to IV with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). This combination therapy has been shown to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and hospitalization for heart failure in adult patients with chronic heart failure. 

 

The mechanism of action involves dual inhibition:

 

  1. Neprilysin Inhibition: Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin, an enzyme responsible for degrading vasoactive peptides such as natriuretic peptides, bradykinin, and adrenomedullin. By inhibiting neprilysin, sacubitril increases the levels of these peptides, leading to vasodilation, natriuresis, and diuresis, which collectively reduce the workload on the heart. 
  2. Angiotensin II Receptor Blockade: Valsartan blocks the angiotensin II type-1 (AT1) receptor, thereby inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This blockade results in vasodilation and a reduction in the release of aldosterone, which decreases sodium and water retention, further alleviating stress on the cardiovascular system. 

 

The combination of these mechanisms addresses both the detrimental effects of RAAS activation and enhances the beneficial effects of increased vasoactive peptides, providing a comprehensive approach to managing heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacubitril/Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) indicated for treating NYHA class II to IV heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, functioning by inhibiting the RAAS and increasing levels of beneficial vasoactive peptides.

questions.text: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for her myopia. She is now complaining of headaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on her: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tonometry

 

  • The image depicts the use of an Applanation tonometry. It is based on the applanation principle described by Imbert and Fick. With regards to applanation tonometry, the law states that pressure (P) can be approximated by the force (F) necessary to flatten the cornea in a fixed area, divided by the surface (S) of the flattened area. The Imbert-Fick law is defined as P=F/S.
  • The dynamic contour tonometer (Pascal) for tonometry looks as

 

 

  • Intraocular pressure (IOP) readings obtained with this tonometer are not influenced by central corneal thickness.
  • The Pascal tonometer is the preferred tonometer for measuring IOP in post-LASIK corneas.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pachymetry: This test measures the thickness of the cornea. It is important for assessing the cornea pre-LASIK but is not depicted in the image nor directly associated with measuring IOP.

 

 

Option C. Autorefractometry: This procedure determines the refractive error and prescription for glasses or contact lenses. It does not involve contact with the eye as depicted and is unrelated to IOP measurement.

 

 

Option D. A scan: This ultrasound test measures the length of the eye and is primarily used in cataract surgery planning. It does not involve the measurement of IOP.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tonometry, especially applanation tonometry, is crucial for monitoring intraocular pressure post-LASIK surgery to ensure no adverse effects on eye pressure, which could lead to symptoms like headaches and eye pain as described. This test is essential for the ongoing evaluation of patients' eye health following refractive surgery.

choices.text: Platelets is stored between 20°c to 24°C with a shelf life of 5 days
Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°C with a shelf life of 6 months
Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol and saline is stored between -5°C to -15 °C with a shelf life of 5 weeks
Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15° C with a shelf life of 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about blood products? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelets is stored between 20° C to 24° C with a shelf life of 5 days

 

Platelets can be stored at temperatures ranging from 20°C to 24°C, and they have a shelf life of 5 days (with continuous agitation) 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°C with a shelf life of 6 months: This statement is incorrect because cryoprecipitate is typically stored at temperatures between -18°C to -30°C with a shelf life of 1 year. Cryoprecipitate is rich in clotting factors like fibrinogen, Factor VIII, and von Willebrand factor.

 

Option C. Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol, and saline is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 5 weeks: This statement is incorrect. Packed red blood cells stored with solutions like SAGM (Saline, Adenine, Glucose, Mannitol) are typically stored at temperatures between 2°C to 6°C, not -5°C to -15°C, and they have a shelf life of up to 42 days, not 5 weeks.

 

Option D. Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 2 years: This statement is incorrect. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is usually stored at temperatures between -18°C to -30°C and has a shelf life of 1 year.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-coagulants solution and shelf life

questions.text: You're a physician attending a conference on emerging infectious diseases. As the discussion shifts towards the recent outbreaks in South India, the speaker displays an image showcasing the life cycle of a specific virus. A fellow physician sitting beside you, being relatively unfamiliar with the recent disease trends in South India, asks for your insights about the virus in question. Given the depicted life cycle and the associated clinical syndromes, which of the following viruses would be the most likely culprit? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Nipah virus

 

NIPAH Virus

 

  • Genus: Henapi virus
  • Transmission in India:
    • Occurrence: West Bengal, Kerela (Kozhikode district)
    • Route: Consumption of fruits contaminated with bats (Pteropus: ‘Flying foxes’) secretions (person - person in India) 
    • Direct contact with infected bats, infected pigs, infected people
  • Clinical presentation: Encephalitis
  • IP is 4-14 days
  • Case fatality rate: 50%
  • Vaccine: NONE for humans
  • Treatment: Intensive supportive care
    • High-risk contacts and healthcare workers, who are under quarantine and monitoring for 21 days
  • WHO included Nipah virus under list of Emerging Diseases likely to cause Major Epidemics 
  • Comes under Category C of Bioterrorism agent 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Japanese encephalitis: Transmitted by mosquitoes and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Option B. Zika virus: Transmitted by mosquitoes, primarily the Aedes species, and does not match the transmission cycle shown in the image.

 

ZIKA VIRUS LIFE CYCLE

 

 

 

Option C. Rabies: Transmitted through the bites of infected animals (typically dogs or other mammals) and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nipah virus, transmitted through fruit bats and causing encephalitis, fits the transmission cycle shown in the image and is a significant emerging infectious disease in regions such as Malaysia and Bangladesh.

choices.text: Excretion in saliva
Excretion in urine
Large volume of distribution
Small volume of distribution

questions.text: Which of the following suggests storage of drugs in tissue (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Large volume of distribution

 

Large volume of distribution suggests storage of drugs in tissue. The volume of distribution (Vd) is a pharmacokinetic parameter that reflects the extent of drug distribution throughout the body. A large Vd indicates that a drug is extensively distributed throughout the tissues, including organs and fluids. This suggests that the drug is likely to be stored in the tissues and may have a long half-life. In contrast, a small Vd indicates that the drug is primarily confined to the bloodstream and has limited distribution to the tissues. Excretion in saliva or urine does not necessarily suggest storage of drugs in tissues, and the volume of distribution is not directly related to excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excretion in saliva: Excretion in saliva does not provide direct information about the extent of drug distribution or storage in tissues. It is more related to the route of elimination.

 

Option B. Excretion in urine: Excretion in urine indicates renal elimination of the drug or its metabolites. It provides information about the drug's elimination route but not about its distribution or storage in tissues.

 

Option D. Small volume of distribution: A small Vd indicates that the drug is largely confined to the bloodstream and has limited distribution to the tissues. This means the drug is not significantly stored in the tissues and is more likely to be readily available in the blood for excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A large volume of distribution (Vd) suggests that a drug is extensively distributed and stored in the body's tissues, which can result in a prolonged half-life and slower elimination from the body.

choices.text: Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.text: All the following PFT findings in a child are suggestive of asthma except? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Day- night variation of FEV1 > 12%

 

A day-night variation of FEV1 > 12%, is not a standard measure used in the diagnosis of asthma. While diurnal variation in peak expiratory flow (PEF) is often used to monitor asthma control, it is not specifically measured by FEV1, and a >12% variation in FEV1 between day and night is not typically used as a diagnostic criterion for asthma.

 

Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs) are essential in diagnosing and managing asthma, particularly in identifying airflow obstruction and its reversibility. Specific findings on PFTs suggestive of asthma include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation: An increase in FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second) by more than 15% after the administration of a bronchodilator like salbutamol is indicative of reversible airway obstruction, which is characteristic of asthma.

 

Option B. FEV1/FVC< 80%: A FEV1/FVC (Forced Vital Capacity) ratio of less than 80% is suggestive of obstructive lung disease, including asthma. This ratio decreases because of the increased airway resistance in asthmatic patients.

 

Option D. Decrease in FEV1>12% after exercise: A decrease in FEV1 by more than 15% after exercise is a sign of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, a common feature of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in FEV1 > 12% after bronchodilator use and a FEV1/FVC ratio < 80% are key PFT findings suggestive of asthma.

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Complementation

 

The image shows a blue-white assay which uses the phenomenon of complementation (complementation of the galactosidase gene).

 

Blue-white assay: The target DNA is inserted into a vector. Vector is introduced into host cells for transformation and it grows in the presence of X-gal (X-gal detects active galactosidase). White colonies arise when cells are transformed with recombinant DNA-containing vectors; blue colonies form when cells are transformed with non-recombinant plasmids (i.e., just the vector).

 

Interpretation of Colonies:

 

  • White Colonies: These arise when the lacZ gene is disrupted by the insertion of foreign DNA, preventing the production of active beta-galactosidase. This indicates successful insertion of the foreign DNA.
  • Green Colonies: (Typically represented as blue colonies in traditional descriptions) These form when the lacZ gene remains intact, producing active beta-galactosidase that cleaves X-Gal, resulting in a blue color. This indicates the vector did not take up the foreign DNA or the insert is outside the lacZ gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Translation: This process involves the synthesis of proteins from mRNA and is not related to the phenomenon shown in the image.

 

Option B. Transformation: While transformation is a part of the process where bacterial cells take up the plasmid DNA, the specific phenomenon depicted is complementation in the blue-white screening assay.

 

Option D. Conjugation: This is a method of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria involving direct cell-to-cell contact and is unrelated to the process shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blue-white screening assay uses the complementation of the beta-galactosidase gene to distinguish between bacterial colonies with recombinant and non-recombinant plasmids based on the color change in the presence of X-Gal.

choices.text: On the action line
Before the action line
On the alert line
After the alert line

questions.text: In a Partogram, where do you start plotting the cervical dilatation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) On the alert line

 

Explanation:

 

In the WHO modified partograph, labor progression is charted using alert and action lines. The cervical dilatation is plotted starting in the active phase of labor, typically at 4 cm dilation.

 

  • Alert Line: Represents a cervical dilation rate of 1 cm per hour. The first marking of cervical dilatation should be on this line.
  • Action Line: Plotted 4 hours to the right of the alert line. It indicates when intervention should be considered if labor is not progressing as expected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. On the action line: Plotting starts on the alert line, not the action line. The action line is used for intervention planning.

 

Option B. Before the action line: This is incorrect as the plotting starts on the alert line.

 

Option D. After the alert line: This is incorrect since plotting should start on the alert line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a Partogram, cervical dilatation is first plotted on the alert line, which indicates the expected rate of progress in labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

choices.text: They are unable to mount inflammation against the virus
Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA
There is a risk of elevation of transaminases
Liver parenchymal cells are in a state of high proliferation

questions.text: There are 3 to 5% healthy hepatitis B carriers in India who are asymptomatic. They are at the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma in the future because? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA

 

In most tumors, HBV DNA is integrated into the cell genome, and in most cases, the virus DNA has undergone rearrangements, including deletions. After integration, it promotes the overexpression of cell genes that can also contribute to oncogenesis.

 

The only viral gene product that is consistently present in the tumor cells is the X protein.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Inability to mount inflammation against the virus is not the primary reason for the increased risk of HCC.

 

Option C: Elevated transaminases indicate liver inflammation but are not directly related to the integration of viral DNA and oncogenesis.

 

Option D: High proliferation of liver parenchymal cells is not the primary reason for the increased risk of HCC due to HBV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B virus can integrate its DNA into the host genome, leading to genetic mutations and increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in all of the following conditions except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Male infertility

 

Pulsatile exposure to GnRH induces FSH/LH secretion while sustained exposure de-sensitizes the receptors resulting in decrease in secretion of gonadotropins. Therefore, non-pulsatile (continuous) GnRH agonists are given when we want to decrease the sex hormones.

 

Indications:-

 

  •  Prostatic carcinoma
  •  Endometriosis
  •  Precocious puberty
  •  Fibroid

 

But in case of male infertility, more testosterone is required to induce spermatogenesis, so GnRH agonists are given in pulsatile manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: In endometriosis, continuous GnRH agonists are used to lower estrogen levels, which helps reduce the growth of endometrial tissue and alleviate symptoms.

 

Option C. Central precocious puberty: Continuous GnRH agonists are used to decrease sex hormone levels, thereby delaying early onset puberty.

 

Option D. Prostate cancer: Continuous GnRH agonists reduce testosterone levels, which helps in managing prostate cancer by slowing down the growth of cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-pulsatile (continuous) GnRH agonists are used to decrease sex hormone levels in conditions such as endometriosis, central precocious puberty, and prostate cancer. In male infertility, pulsatile GnRH agonists are used to increase testosterone and induce spermatogenesis.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 262,263

choices.text: Dexamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 2 doses
Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 12 hourly 2 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 4 doses

questions.text: What is the dose of corticosteroids for lung maturity? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses

 

Corticosteroids are administered to pregnant women who are at risk of preterm delivery (before 34 weeks of gestation) to enhance fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. The correct dosing regimen for corticosteroids is crucial for their effectiveness.

 

Dexamethasone and Betamethasone are the two corticosteroids commonly used for this purpose:

 

  • Dexamethasone is given as 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours, totaling four doses. This regimen ensures adequate fetal lung maturation by delivering consistent steroid levels over 48 hours.
  • Betamethasone is typically administered as 12 mg intramuscularly, given in two doses 24 hours apart. This regimen also effectively promotes fetal lung maturity but involves fewer doses compared to Dexamethasone.

 

In this specific case, the correct answer is Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses because it follows the standard protocol for promoting lung maturity in fetuses at risk of preterm birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For fetal lung maturity, the standard dosing regimen of Dexamethasone is 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours for a total of 4 doses. This regimen is effective in reducing the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants.

choices.text: Ejaculation
Dilation of bronchus
Increased cardiac contractility

questions.text: Muscarinic receptor stimulation primarily causes which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Erection

 

  • Parasympathetic (muscarinic) stimulation result in erection whereas sympathetic stimulation causes ejaculation.
  • Parasympathetic system causes bronchoconstriction whereas sympathetic system result in bronchodilation.
  • Increase in cardiac contractility is primarily action of beta 1 receptors of the heart.

 

Mnemonic

 

Point and Shoot:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ejaculation: Ejaculation is primarily mediated by the sympathetic nervous system, not the parasympathetic system. Thus, muscarinic receptor stimulation does not cause ejaculation.

 

Option C. Dilation of bronchus: The parasympathetic system causes bronchoconstriction. Bronchodilation is mediated by the sympathetic nervous system.

 

Option D. Increased cardiac contractility: Increased cardiac contractility is primarily an action of beta-1 adrenergic receptors, which are part of the sympathetic nervous system. Muscarinic receptor stimulation generally results in decreased heart rate and contractility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscarinic receptor stimulation is associated with parasympathetic responses such as erection, while sympathetic stimulation is responsible for ejaculation, bronchodilation, and increased cardiac contractility.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Collar stud appearance  

 

The provided image depicts the right fundus of a patient, which indicates the presence of choroidal melanoma.

 

  • Angiography of the lesion: shows a distinct "double circulation" pattern, which represents the internal circulation within the tumor and the normal vascularity of the overlying retina.
  • On B-scan: pathognomonic feature called the "collar stud appearance" is visible. This appearance refers to a raised, dome-shaped tumor with a collar-like thickening at the base, caused by the accumulation of melanin and the infiltration of inflammatory cells at the tumor base.

 

 

Choroidal melanoma is a type of cancer that originates in the choroid, which is the vascular layer of the eye located between the retina and the sclera. It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults and can lead to visual impairment and even metastasis to other organs. Therefore, it is crucial to diagnose and manage it promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smoke-stack appearance: Typically associated with central serous retinopathy, showing a smoke-like leakage of fluid under the retina.

 

Option B. Inkblot appearance: Another pattern seen in central serous retinopathy where fluid leaks in a blot-like fashion.

 

Option D. Double circulation: While this feature can be seen in angiography of choroidal melanoma, it does not describe the ultrasonography appearance, which is specifically asked in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When diagnosing choroidal melanoma via ultrasonography, the "collar stud appearance" is a key finding. Recognizing this feature, along with the clinical presentation of painless visual loss and metamorphopsia, supports a timely and accurate diagnosis of this potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the OPD with a painless deformity. A radiograph of the child's legs is shown below. The most common cause of this deformity is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickets

 

The X-ray shows bow legs or genu varum, which is most commonly seen in rickets. Rickets is a bone mineralization disorder that primarily affects children with open growth plates, resulting from a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. This deficiency leads to improper bone mineralization and structural deformities, especially in weight-bearing bones such as the legs.

 

Common radiological features of rickets include:

 

  • Loss of the provisional zone of calcification (the earliest sign)
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of the growth plate
  • Cupping and fraying of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of the diaphysis

 

In toddlers, genu varum is one of the most common initial signs of rickets. Other clinical features, such as frontal bossing, rachitic rosary, and delayed closure of fontanelles, may also be present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skeletal dysplasia: Skeletal dysplasia refers to a group of disorders affecting bone growth and development, but it does not typically present with the classical features of rickets.

 

Option C. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of vitamin C and primarily affects collagen formation, leading to bleeding gums, poor wound healing, and bone pain, but it is not associated with the characteristic bowing of the legs seen in rickets.

 

Option D. Blount disease: Blount disease is a growth disorder of the tibia (shinbone) causing it to angle inward, but it typically affects older children and adolescents and has a different radiographic appearance than rickets.

 

Educational Objective:


Rickets is the most common cause of bone deformities like genu varum in children. It results from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, leading to improper bone development, particularly in areas with rapid growth like the knees and wrists.

choices.text: Stop the treatment and follow up
Continue treatment for another 2 years
Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment
Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics

questions.text: A 16-year-old who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would be your advice? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continue treatment for another 2 years

 

In cases of epilepsy, particularly in children and adolescents, the continuation of antiepileptic drug (AED) therapy after a period of being seizure-free is typically recommended for about 2 years. This recommendation is based on the need to stabilize neurological function and minimize the risk of recurrence. The decision to discontinue AEDs should consider factors such as the duration of being seizure-free, EEG findings, the type of epilepsy, and the individual’s neurological examination.

 

Rationale for Continuing Treatment:

 

  • Continuing AED treatment for at least 2 years after achieving seizure control helps ensure the stability of the condition and reduces the likelihood of seizure recurrence, especially during the critical developmental years of adolescence.
  • Recurrences are most common in the first 3 months after discontinuing AEDs, making a cautious approach necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop the treatment and follow up: This would be risky given the short period of seizure freedom (only 6 months). Stopping treatment prematurely may lead to recurrence.

 

Option C. Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment: This is typically considered after a longer period of seizure freedom, usually a minimum of 2 years, not just 6 months.

 

Option D. Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics: This is generally reserved for cases of refractory epilepsy where seizures cannot be controlled with multiple medications, which does not seem to be the case here based on the information provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-epileptics once initiated must be continued for a minimum period of 2 years. Decision to stop AED is considered if, seizure free > 2 years with normal MRI, EEG, seizure type.

 

Recurrences occur in the first 3 months of discontinuing AED.

 

Reference - Harrison principles of internal Medicine 21st edition Pg. 12076

questions.text: Which of the following stains cause brown color to Her 2 neu cells of breast carcinoma as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diamino benzidene

 

  • Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is commonly used as a chromogen in immunohistochemistry. It reacts with the peroxidase enzyme in a substrate solution, producing a brown precipitate that is visible under a microscope, marking the antigen-antibody binding site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein Isothiocyanate: This is a fluorochrome and not used for color development in traditional histopathological stains, but rather for fluorescence microscopy.

 

Option B. Alkaline Phosphatase: This enzyme can be used in immunohistochemistry, typically resulting in red or blue stains, depending on the substrate used, not brown.

 

Option D. Benzene: This is an organic solvent and not used as a chromogen in histopathology or immunohistochemistry.

 

Educational objective:

 

For staining specific proteins like Her2 in breast carcinoma tissues, diaminobenzidine (DAB) is a preferred chromogen for peroxidase-mediated reactions in immunohistochemistry, yielding a distinct brown coloration which highlights the presence of the target antigen.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿A - Aspirin, B - Eptifibatide, C - Vorapaxar
﻿﻿﻿A - Aspirin, B - Eptifibatide, C - Prasugrel
﻿﻿﻿A - Aspirin, B - Prasugrel, C - Eptifibatide

questions.text: Identify the drugs marked as A, B, and C:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A - Aspirin, B - Eptifibatide, C - Vorapaxar
 

The drugs marked A, B and C are aspirin, eptifibatide, and vorapaxar, respectively.

 

  • Aspirin exhibits its antiplatelet action by inhibiting the COX-1 enzyme and decreasing the synthesis of Thromboxane A2.
  • Eptifibatide is a Gp IIb/IIIa receptor blocker. Others being Abciximab and Tirofiban.
  • Vorapaxar acts on the thrombin receptors on the platelets- the PAR-1 (Protease Activated Receptor-1). Thrombin binds to the platelets with the help of this receptor and leads to platelet aggregation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct identification of antiplatelet drugs and their mechanisms of action is crucial for understanding their roles in preventing platelet aggregation and managing cardiovascular conditions. Aspirin inhibits COX-1, Eptifibatide blocks Gp IIb/IIIa receptors, and Vorapaxar inhibits the PAR-1 receptor.

questions.text: A patient presented to emergency with overdose some drug. There were increased salivation and increased bronchial secretions. On examination, blood pressure was 88/60 mmHg. RBC esterase level is 50. What should be the treatment of this person?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atropine

 

  • Low esterase levels are suggestive of overdose of some drug which acts by inhibiting acetyl choline esterase like organophosphate poisoning.
  • Inhibition of choline esterase results in increased amount of Ach at synapse, so poisoning or overdose results in cholinergic symptoms like salivation, lacrimation, urination, emesis, increased bronchial secretions, and reduction in blood pressure.
    So treatment of choice is Atropine.
  • Atropine - It is highly effective in counter-acting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects. It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action. All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly treated with atropine 2 mg i.v. repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear (upto 200 mg has been administered in a day). Continued treatment with maintenance doses may be required for 1-2 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is incorrect as it is an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor, which would worsen the cholinergic symptoms by increasing acetylcholine levels further.

 

Option C. Flumazenil: Flumazenil is incorrect because it is an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose, not for organophosphate poisoning. It works by antagonizing the effects of benzodiazepines on the central nervous system.

 

Option D. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is incorrect as it is also an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor, which would exacerbate the symptoms of cholinergic overdose. Additionally, it is used to treat atropine poisoning, not organophosphate poisoning.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of organophosphate poisoning, which presents with cholinergic symptoms and low RBC esterase levels, the treatment of choice is atropine, administered intravenously until signs of atropinization appear.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/122

questions.text:
Arrange the following external fixators used for treatment of fracture of tibia in order of increasing stability: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Ilizarov

  2. Uniplanar frame with one rod

  3. Biplanar frame

  4. Uniplanar frame with two rods
questions.solution:
Ans. A. II, IV, III, I

 

EXTERNAL FIXATION

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin.

  • Uniplanar frame with one rod provides the least stability as it can only resist forces in one plane.

  • In uniplanar frame with two rods, adding a second rod increases stability compared to a single rod.

  • Biplanar frame provides stability in two planes, making it more secure than uniplanar frames. It improves the resistance to rotational and bending forces.

  • The Ilizarov external fixator is known for its exceptional stability due to its ring structure and multiple pins. It provides high axial and torsional stability.

  • It is often used for complex fractures and lengthening procedures.

  • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis i.e., an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done.

  • It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.

  • Therefore, the Ilizarov fixator offers the highest level of stability among the options listed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the fixation of tibia fracture, the order of external fixators used in order of increased stability is:

 

Uniplanar frame with one rod (II) < uniplanar frame with two rods (IV) < biplanar frame (III) < ilizarov (I)

questions.text: Least frequency of slow waves is seen in? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stomach

 

Among the given options, the least frequency of slow waves is seen in the stomach (4/min).

 

Most gastrointestinal contractions occur rhythmically, and this rhythm is determined mainly by the frequency of so-called “slow waves” of smooth muscle membrane potential or basal electrical rhythm.

 

Interactions among the smooth muscle cells and specialized cells, called the interstitial cells of Cajal, that are believed to act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

 

They are slow, undulating changes in the resting membrane potential. Their intensity usually varies between 5 and 15 millivolts, and their frequency ranges in different parts of the human gastrointestinal tract from 3 to 12 per minute:

 

  • Body of the stomach – 3/min
  • Duodenum – 12/min
  • Terminal ileum – 8-9/min
  • Distal ileum: 8/min
  • Cecum: 2/min
  • Sigmoid colon: 6/min

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenum: Incorrect. The duodenum has a higher frequency of slow waves, approximately 12 waves per minute.

 

Option B. Ileum: Incorrect. The terminal ileum has a frequency of about 8-9 waves per minute.

 

Option C. Jejunum: Incorrect. The jejunum has a frequency of approximately 10-12 waves per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stomach has the least frequency of slow waves among the given options, with approximately 3 waves per minute. Slow waves determine the rhythmic contractions of the gastrointestinal tract and vary in frequency throughout different regions.

questions.text: Low apparent volume of distribution of drug indicates?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Not extensively distributed to tissues

 

Apparent Volume of distribution (Vd) = dose administered I.V/ plasma concentration It indicates how extensively the drug is distributed in the tissues. For example, Chloroquine has the highest volume of distribution, as it is mostly distributed to the liver and a very small amount is left for the action on RBC.

 

E.g.: If a 1000 mg of drug A is given i.v (100% bioavailability) and the plasma concentration reached is 10 mg/ liter then the apparent volume of distribution (Vd) is 1000/10= 10 liters.

 

But the normal blood volume is about 5 liters. A high Vd is due to accumulation of drug A being distributed in extravascular tissues resulting in low plasma concentration.

 

Half-life or t1/2 relationship with volume of distribution (Vd) and clearance (CI) is given by the formula t 1/2 = 0.693 × Vd /CI. t1/2 is directly proportional to Vd but it is also inversely proportional to clearance. If a drug has a low volume of distribution but clearance is very low, t1/2 can still be high. So low Vd doesn't always imply low t1/2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low t 1/2: The half-life (t1/2) of a drug is influenced by both its volume of distribution (Vd) and its clearance (Cl). It is given by the formula:

 

t1/2=0.693×Vd/Cl

 

A low Vd does not necessarily imply a low half-life, as the half-life is also dependent on the clearance of the drug. If the clearance is low, the half-life can still be long despite a low Vd.

 

Option B. Low bioavailability: Bioavailability refers to the fraction of an administered dose of a drug that reaches the systemic circulation in an unchanged form. It is primarily affected by the route of administration and first-pass metabolism, not by the volume of distribution.

 

Option C. Low efficacy: Efficacy refers to the ability of a drug to produce a desired therapeutic effect. It is determined by the drug’s mechanism of action and intrinsic activity at its target receptors, not by its volume of distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A low apparent volume of distribution (Vd) indicates that the drug is not extensively distributed to tissues and remains largely confined to the blood plasma. This parameter is essential for understanding the pharmacokinetic behavior of the drug in the body.

questions.text: Dr. Radhika, the district health officer, is evaluating the efficiency of a subcenter in a rural region of India. This subcenter services a population of 5,000 people, and it has been reported that the crude birth rate (CBR) in this region stands at 20 per 1,000 people. Dr. Radhika wants to ensure that every pregnant woman receives antenatal care (ANC) to promote healthy pregnancies and reduce complications. With the current CBR, how many ANC registrations should the village health nurse (VHN) expect to handle annually? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 60

 

Calculation 

 

A subcentre serves a population of 5000 in plains.

 

CBR given is 20.

 

Expected number of pregnancies can be calculated by: Birth rate x population of the area / 1000 = 20 × 5000/1000 = 100.

 

A correction factor of 10% is added to adjust for pregnancy wastage in the form of abortions or stillbirths.

 

Hence, total number of expected pregnancies = Expected number of pregnancies + 10% of the same = 100 + 10 = 110

 

 Since not all pregnancies are officially registered, an Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) is typically expected to have at least half of the anticipated pregnancies under her care registered at any point in time. Therefore, the count of Antenatal Care (ANC) registrations is calculated as 50% of the projected pregnancies.

 

Therefore, Total ANC registrations expected = total number of expected pregnancies/2 = 55

 

The closest answer is 60.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In assessing ANC needs based on CBR in a rural health setting, it's crucial to accurately apply demographic statistics to the actual population size.
  • Expectations should align with direct calculations unless specific adjustments are warranted by local conditions or policies.

choices.text: Located in the thick muscle layer
Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch
Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about baroreceptors? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Located in the thick muscle layer

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer of the carotid bulb of the internal carotid artery (not in the thick muscle layer); where the walls are typically thinner to allow for the detection of pressure changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stretch receptors: Baroreceptors are indeed stretch receptors; they respond to the stretching of the arterial wall as blood pressure changes.

 

Option C. Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch: Afferent fibers from the carotid sinus baroreceptors pass through the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) to the brainstem.

 

Option D. Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure: Baroreceptors are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure; they quickly respond to fluctuations in blood pressure by sending signals to the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer, not in the thick muscle layer, and they are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure, functioning as stretch receptors with afferent fibers passing via the glossopharyngeal nerve.`1

questions.text: Glucosamines are used in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arthritis

 

Glucosamine and chondroitin sulphate are used in the treatment of arthritis which is a degenerative joint disease.

 

Glucosamines are amino sugars. Mucopolysaccharides or glycosamino glycans (GAG) are heteropolysaccharides, containing uronic acid and amino sugars. Acetylated amino groups, sulfate and carboxyl groups are also generally present. Because of the presence of these charged groups, they attract water molecules and so they produce viscous solutions.

 

Examples of mucopolysaccharides are hyaluronic acid, heparin, chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate and keratan sulfate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niemann-Pick disease: This is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by the accumulation of sphingomyelin, not treated with glucosamines.

 

Option C. Alzheimer's disease: This neurodegenerative condition involves the accumulation of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Glucosamines are not used in its treatment.

 

Option D. Cancer: Cancer treatment involves a wide range of therapies such as chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and immunotherapy. Glucosamines are not used in cancer treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucosamine is used in the treatment of arthritis due to its role in maintaining healthy cartilage and joint function.

choices.text: SBP > 140 mm Hg and DBP < 90 mmHg

questions.text: All of the factors would suggest a higher risk for a patient with TIA developing stroke in the future according to ABCD2 scoring except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age < 60 years

 

The ABCD2 score is a clinical tool used to predict the short-term risk of stroke after a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The scoring system includes several factors that help assess this risk. Here’s why option A is the correct answer:

 

  • Age < 60 years: According to the ABCD2 scoring system, a patient who is aged 60 years or older scores 1 point, indicating a higher risk. Therefore, being younger than 60 does not contribute to an increased score, making it the correct choice for the exception in this question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duration of TIA > 5 mins: In the ABCD2 score, the duration of the TIA is an important factor. TIA lasting 10-59 minutes scores 1 point, and TIA lasting more than 60 minutes scores 2 points. Duration less than 10 minutes would score 0. However, since the option simply says "Duration of TIA > 5 mins," without specifying how much longer, it's less clearly defined in this question, but generally longer durations imply a higher score.

 

Option C. SBP > 140 mm Hg and DBP < 90 mmHg: High blood pressure at the time of TIA, defined as SBP ≥ 140 mm Hg or DBP ≥ 90 mm Hg, scores 1 point in the ABCD2 score.

 

Option D. Diabetes: The presence of diabetes in a patient who has experienced a TIA adds 1 point to the ABCD2 score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional D3-Dual TIA (within 7 days of first TIA), Imaging (MRI, DWI) were added to original score. However, all these perform very poorly in the light of recent evidences.

questions.text: Which of the following is a new approved drug for Rett syndrome. (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trofinetide

 

Rett syndrome is an X-linked genetic disorder mostly seen in females. Symptoms include impairments in language and coordination, and repetitive movements. It occurs due to mutation in MECP2 gene.

 

Trofinetide is an analog of glypromate or glycine–proline–glutamate (GPE), a naturally occurring protein in the brain and the N-terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1). GPE exhibits neuroprotective properties: it protects neurons from glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity and oxidative stress.

 

Trofinetide has similar neuroprotective properties and has longer half-life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zavegepant: This is a CGRP antagonist approved for the treatment of migraine, not for Rett syndrome.

 

Option C. Sparsentan: This is a dual endothelin antagonist and angiotensin receptor antagonist approved for the treatment of IgA nephropathy, not Rett syndrome.

 

Option D. Elacestrant: This is a selective estrogen receptor downregulator approved as an oral treatment for breast cancer, not Rett syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trofinetide is a newly approved drug for Rett syndrome, exhibiting neuroprotective properties similar to those of glypromate (GPE), and is beneficial for treating the symptoms of this genetic disorder.

questions.text: Identify the device given below.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chemoport

 

The image shows a chemoport. Chemoports are implantable venous access devices specifically designed to facilitate the administration of chemotherapy in patients. These devices allow for repeated access to the venous system, making them suitable for long-term use in cancer treatment. They are implanted under the skin, typically in the chest area, with the catheter inserted into large veins, commonly the internal jugular or subclavian veins. The device remains in place for 1 to 2 years or longer, depending on the treatment requirements, and is later explanted once it is no longer needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dialysis port: A dialysis port is a device used to provide vascular access for hemodialysis. It has a different design and is intended specifically for dialysis treatments rather than chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Electro-convulsive therapy lead : This lead is used in electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) to deliver electric currents to the brain for therapeutic purposes in certain psychiatric conditions. It has no use in chemotherapy administration or venous access.

 

 

Option D. Gamma camera : A gamma camera is a diagnostic imaging device used in nuclear medicine to visualize the distribution of radioactive tracers in the body. It is not an implantable device and has no function in delivering chemotherapy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A chemoport is an implantable venous access device used for administering chemotherapy, commonly placed in large veins like the internal jugular or subclavian veins.

questions.text: Which surgical procedure should a 21-year-old boxer avoid to maintain optimal visual health? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RK

 

  • For a 21-year-old boxer who needs to maintain optimal visual health, understanding the differences between various refractive surgeries is crucial. 

 

Involves making radial cuts in the cornea to change its shape and correct refractive errors. It's not recommended for boxers because it weakens the structural integrity of the eye, making it more vulnerable to trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PRK (Photorefractive Keratectomy): This surgery involves removing the surface layer of the cornea to reshape it with a laser. It is safer than RK for athletes because it does not involve creating a flap, which could dislocate upon impact, though recovery can be slower.

 

Option C. LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis): LASIK surgery also reshapes the cornea but through creating a thin flap in the outer layer. While popular due to quick recovery times and immediate results, the flap might pose a risk in contact sports, as it could dislodge or move from direct impact.

 

Option D. SMILE (Small Incision Lenticule Extraction): The newest form of laser eye surgery, SMILE involves making a small, lenticule-shaped cut inside the cornea to reshape it without creating a flap. It offers a potentially safer option for athletes as it maintains more of the cornea's structural integrity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For a boxer, avoiding procedures that compromise the cornea's physical integrity is crucial due to the high risk of impacts to the face. Among these options, RK and potentially LASIK present higher risks. SMILE or PRK might be safer alternatives, providing effective vision correction with a reduced risk of severe complications from physical trauma.

choices.text: Repeat Colposcopy and biopsy after 6 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came for routine PAP smear testing. The report came as HSIL. On colposcopy and biopsy, it was confirmed to be carcinoma in situ. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conization

 

Explanation:

 

Carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix is classified as Stage 0 cancer. In a young woman with stage 0 cervical cancer, the management of choice is conization. Conization involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix, including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix. This procedure serves both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes:

 

  • Diagnostic: Conization provides a tissue specimen for histopathological examination, which is more definitive compared to a cytological specimen obtained from a Pap smear.
  • Therapeutic: If the histopathology shows clear margins, conization can be curative for carcinoma in situ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysterectomy: This is a more radical treatment and is generally reserved for cases where there is invasive cancer or other indications. It is not the first-line treatment for CIS in a young woman.

 

Option C. Repeat colposcopy and biopsy after 6 months: In the case of confirmed carcinoma in situ, conization is preferred. There is no need of repeat colpobiopsy 

 

Option D. HPV DNA testing: This test is used for screening and risk assessment but is not a treatment for confirmed carcinoma in situ.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conization, which involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix, is the management of choice for carcinoma in situ in young women. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic if histopathology shows clear margins.

 

 

Ref: Page no 992, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase
Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling

questions.text: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OD for vaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) All killed vaccines under NIS can be given

 

In children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, the approach to vaccination must be carefully considered, particularly due to their immunocompromised state from corticosteroid therapy.

 

  • Killed (inactivated) vaccines are safe and can be administered to these children as they do not pose a risk of causing disease. This includes vaccines such as the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV), diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine, and others under the National Immunization Schedule (NIS).
  • Live vaccines should be administered with caution. For children on corticosteroid therapy, live vaccines (e.g., MMR, varicella) are generally avoided unless the child is on low-dose corticosteroids (less than 1 mg/kg/day of prednisone or equivalent). Live virus vaccines are contraindicated in children receiving high doses of steroids or other immunosuppressive therapies like cyclophosphamide or cyclosporine.
  • Vaccination of household contacts: It's crucial to vaccinate healthy household contacts with live vaccines to protect the immunosuppressed child indirectly. However, precautions should be taken to avoid contact with the secretions of recently vaccinated individuals, particularly in the case of live oral vaccines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule: This is not accurate as live vaccines should be given with caution or avoided in immunocompromised children, particularly those on high-dose steroids.

 

Option C. Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in the acute phase: While the pneumococcal vaccine is important, it is not the only vaccine that should be considered. Killed vaccines are generally safe and should be administered according to the vaccination schedule.

 

Option D. Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling: This is incorrect. Siblings and household contacts should receive live vaccines to reduce the risk of transmitting infections to the immunocompromised child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, all killed vaccines under the National Immunization Schedule can be safely administered, while live vaccines should be given with caution depending on the child's immunosuppressive therapy.

choices.text: First degree of heart block

questions.text: Disappearance of loud S1 in mitral stenosis occurs in all except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild MS.

 

Loud S1 can be heard in mild MS also because loud S1 does not depend on severity of MS.

 

Loud S1 is one of the auscultatory hallmarks of MS, however it can be attenuated in a variety of conditions:

 

  • Associated MR
  • Long PR (first degree heart block)
  • CCF
  • Severe AR- regurgitant jet may impinge on AML
  • Calcified valve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: Here, the prolonged PR interval delays the closure of the mitral valve relative to ventricular contraction, often softening or eliminating the loud S1.

 

Option B. AR (Aortic Regurgitation): The regurgitant flow in aortic regurgitation can prevent the mitral valve leaflets from closing tightly and sharply, thus softening the S1.

 

Option C. Calcified valve: Calcification of the mitral valve leads to stiffening of the leaflets, which inhibits their rapid movement and thus reduces the intensity of S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mitral stenosis, a loud S1 is typically present unless there is an associated condition that affects the mobility or timing of the mitral valve leaflet closure, such as calcification, regurgitation in other valves, or disturbances in electrical conduction that affect heart rhythm

questions.text: The following instrument is used for……:  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PAP smear

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shown is that of Ayre's spatula which is used for preparing PAP smear.
  • It is used to scrape the squamocolumnar junction of the cervix while preparing a Pap smear.
  • A cytobrush is used to take endocervical samples
  • The smear is fixed with 95% ethanol

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VIA: This is Visual Inspection under Acetic Acid. This is done by applying acetic acid on the cervix. Any acetowhite area is suspicious for dysplasia. It is done in low resource settings.

 

Option B. VILI: Visual inspection under Lugol Iodine: This is done by applying Lugol’s iodine on the cervix. A dysplastic area will not take up iodine. It is also done in low resource settings.

 

 

Option D. Colposcopy: This is a magnified view of the cervix. It is done in patients with abnormal pap smear/ HPV +Ve/ VIA +ve or VILI +ve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ayre's spatula is used for preparing a Pap smear by scraping cells from the cervix for cytological examination.

 

Ref: Page no 325, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: tRNA of Alanine
U6 SnRNA
mRNA for Histone

questions.text: Which of the following does not require 5' capping? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) tRNA of Alanine

 

5’ capping - Eukaryotic mRNAs are all ‘capped’ at the 5′ terminus by 7-methyl guanosine triphosphate. An unusual 5’ to 5′ triphosphate bridge is seen. This happens inside the nucleus. The cap is useful in recognition of mRNA by the translating machinery and in prevention of degradation by exonucleases.

 

Poly-A Tailing at 3′ End - The 3’ terminus is polyadenylated in the nucleoplasm. This

poly-A tail may be 20 to 250 nucleotides long. This tail protects mRNA from attack by 3′ exonuclease.

 

Note: tRNA do not require capping at 5’ end.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. U6 SnRNA:

  • Function: U6 snRNA is part of the spliceosome complex involved in RNA splicing.
  • Modification: U6 snRNA is not typically capped with 7-methyl guanosine but may undergo other modifications.

 

Option C. mRNA for Histone:

  • Function: Histone mRNAs are unique in that they typically do not have poly-A tails but do require 5' capping.
  • Modification: Despite lacking poly-A tails, histone mRNAs still undergo 5' capping.

 

Option D. SiRNA (Small interfering RNA):

  • Function: SiRNAs are involved in the RNA interference pathway, leading to the degradation of target mRNAs.
  • Modification: SiRNAs are typically not capped at the 5' end as they are processed from longer double-stranded RNA precursors.

 

Educational objective:

 

tRNA, including tRNA for alanine, does not require 5' capping. This modification is specific to mRNAs and some snRNAs, playing a critical role in mRNA stability and translation.

questions.text: All of the following can be used to decreased intraocular pressure in glaucoma except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dexamethasone

 

Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid. Corticosteroids are contraindicated in glaucoma because they can lead to an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP). This rise in IOP can exacerbate glaucoma and potentially cause further damage to the optic nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannitol: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic and is the drug of choice for acute congestive glaucoma when administered intravenously. It decreases IOP by creating an osmotic gradient, which helps to draw fluid out of the eye, thereby reducing congestion.

 

Option B. Methazolamide: Methazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It decreases the production of aqueous humor in the eye, which in turn reduces intraocular pressure. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are effective in managing glaucoma.

 

Option C. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. It decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. Alpha-2 agonists are commonly used in the treatment of glaucoma.

  

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note - Dexamethasone is contraindicated in glaucoma

 

Reference: KDT 8th/ 318, 167, 170

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given staining technique? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nocardia asteroids

 

The organism shown above is the Nocardia species. The above image shows acid-fast staining, where the organisms are shown appear as acid-fast (stained with fuschia) and branching rods or filaments. They are aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections in the immunocompromised.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A, B: Mycobacteria species are acid-fast but do not have branching filaments.

 

Option C: Actinomyces species is gram-positive but not acid-fast.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are partially acid-fast, branching, filamentous rods that are found in the soil and cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals.

choices.text: Ascending aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Superior vena-caval syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Abdominal aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Supine vena cava syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supine vena cava syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates supine hypotension syndrome, also known as supine vena cava syndrome. This condition occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava (IVC) while the woman is in a supine position. This compression leads to reduced venous return to the heart, causing hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope. It is especially dangerous during cesarean sections, as spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension. To prevent this, a wedge is placed beneath the right hip during the procedure to tilt the patient slightly to the left, thereby relieving pressure on the vena cava.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ascending aorta syndrome: This condition is not typically associated with pregnancy and does not involve the pressure of the gravid uterus on the IVC.

 

Option B. Superior vena-caval syndrome: This syndrome involves obstruction of the superior vena cava, leading to symptoms such as facial swelling and dyspnea. It is unrelated to the position of a pregnant woman and the compression of the IVC.

 

Option C. Abdominal aorta syndrome: There is no specific syndrome by this name. The abdominal aorta may be compressed during pregnancy, but it does not lead to the symptoms associated with supine hypotension syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine vena cava syndrome occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava when the woman is in a supine position, leading to hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.

 

Ref: Page no 2237, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following topical antifungal has both anti- inflammatory effects and anti-pruritic action? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sertaconazole

 

Sertaconazole has both anti-inflammatory effects and anti-pruritic action. It is used to treat dermatophytosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that also has anti-androgenic effects. However, it does not possess notable anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic properties.

 

Option C. Luliconazole: Luliconazole is effective against dermatophytes and yeasts, but it does not have significant anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic actions.

 

Option D. Terbinafine: Terbinafine is mainly used to treat dermatophytosis. It does not have substantial anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient on anti-tubercular therapy develops tingling sensation in the limbs. Which of the following when substituted can result from in improvement of symptoms? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyridoxine

 

This is a case of peripheral neuropathy that occurs in ATT therapy due to isoniazid (INH)

 

To treat this – Pyridoxine 10-25mg/day should be added to regimen.

 

High risk patients for peripheral neuropathy include- malnutrition, chronic alcohol dependence, diabetes, HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: While important for nervous system function, thiamine is not typically depleted by INH therapy.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Not directly related to the neurological side effects of INH.

 

Option D. Methylcobalamin: Though important for nerve health, it is not the primary vitamin depleted by INH therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation is essential for patients receiving isoniazid as part of their anti-tubercular therapy to prevent or manage peripheral neuropathy symptoms.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug specifically enhances the inactivation phase of voltage-gated slow sodium channels, helping to stabilize hyperexcitable neurons? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lacosamide

 

Explanation:


Lacosamide has a unique mechanism of action among antiepileptic drugs. It selectively enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels. While most sodium channel blocking antiepileptics (like phenytoin, carbamazepine) act on fast sodium channels, lacosamide specifically targets slow sodium channels. This mechanism helps stabilize hyperexcitable neuronal membranes and prevents repetitive neuronal firing.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Phenytoin: Incorrect. While it does act on sodium channels, it primarily blocks fast sodium channels, not slow sodium channels. It acts by promoting the inactive state of these channels.

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Incorrect. Like phenytoin, it acts primarily on fast sodium channels and also affects calcium channels. It does not specifically target slow sodium channels.

 

Option C. Felbamate: Incorrect. It works primarily as an NMDA receptor antagonist and has no significant effect on sodium channels, either fast or slow.

 

Educational Objective:


Lacosamide uniquely acts by enhancing the slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, distinguishing it from other sodium channel-blocking antiepileptics that act on fast sodium channels.

questions.text:
An elderly patient on a vegetarian diet presenting with easy fatigability and pallor was investigated. Peripheral smear showed findings of macrocytic anemia. What is the probable cause of anemia in this patient? Other lab findings are as follows:

 

  • Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL
  • Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 112 fL
  • Serum homocysteine: Elevated
  • Serum methylmalonic acid: Normal
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Folate deficiency

 

The most probable cause of anemia in this patient is folate deficiency. The clinical scenario of macrocytic anemia in a vegetarian patient with elevated homocysteine levels points to megaloblastic anemia. Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by either vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. However, normal methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels in this case suggest folate deficiency as the cause.

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency is usually associated with elevated MMA levels, which are absent here, further supporting folate deficiency as the correct diagnosis.

 

Folate deficiency is associated with the following laboratory findings:

 

  • Increased MCV (macrocytosis)
  • Elevated homocysteine levels
  • Normal MMA levels
  • Decreased reticulocyte count

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alcohol-induced macrocytosis: Although alcohol can cause macrocytosis, it is typically associated with chronic alcohol use. The patient’s history of being on a vegetarian diet and elevated homocysteine levels point away from this as the cause.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12 deficiency: This is a possible cause of macrocytic anemia. However, vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with elevated both homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels. The patient’s normal MMA level makes this option unlikely.

 

Option D. Thiamine deficiency: Thiamine deficiency is primarily associated with neurological issues (e.g., Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome) and is not known to cause macrocytic anemia. Therefore, this is not the correct cause of anemia in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of macrocytic anemia with elevated homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels, folate deficiency should be suspected. In contrast, both elevated homocysteine and MMA levels suggest vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the OPD with a scald injury on his arm. The lesion was pink, oozing, and painful to moving air and touch. Which of the following would be the most appropriate management? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Collagen dressing

 

Scald injury (damage due to contact with hot liquids) that appears pink in colour, has oozing, and pain is suggestive of a 2nd-degree superficial burn (i.e., partial-thickness burn). Collagen dressing is the most appropriate management for this injury.

 

Collagen dressings are an appropriate choice for partial-thickness burn wounds and scald injuries. They provide several advantages, including promoting wound healing, reducing pain, and helping to maintain a moist environment, which is conducive to tissue repair.
