Collagen dressings can be especially helpful in managing painful wounds like scald injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silver Sulphadiazine Cream Dressing: Silver sulfadiazine cream is commonly used for burn wounds. However, in the case of a scald injury like the one described (pink, oozing, and painful), silver sulfadiazine cream may not be the first choice. This cream is used for second degree deep and third degree burns.

 

Option B. Excision and Grafting: Excision and grafting are typically reserved for severe burn injuries that involve full-thickness damage to the skin and underlying tissues. In the case of a pink, oozing, and painful scald injury, which is likely partial-thickness, excision and grafting may be overly aggressive and not necessary.

 

Option C. Paraffin Gauze Dressing: Paraffin gauze dressings are often used for burn wounds. They provide a non-adherent surface and help maintain a moist wound environment. While this dressing may be suitable, collagen dressings (Option D) are better at promoting wound healing and tissue repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best dressing for burn wounds is skin; collagen is a good substitute for skin, especially in partial-thickness burns. For full-thickness burns, sequential excision and grafting must be considered.

 

Initial treatment for burns includes cleaning the burnt areas and removing loose dead skin. Blisters are de-roofed and an appropriate dressing is applied.

 

Biological dressing (collagen dressings, amniotic membrane, etc.) is the preferred dressing material, especially in partial thickness burns.

 

If this is not available then a non-adhesive dressing like paraffin gauze impregnated with silver sulfadiazine (SSD) cream, colloidal silver, ionic silver cream, or silver nitrate cream may be applied. Since increased resistance to SSD has recently emerged, it should be used judiciously and reserved for deep dermal, full thickness, infected, and old neglected burns.

choices.text: Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD20
Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD50
Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD20
Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD50

questions.text: Rituximab is a:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD20

 

Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that acts against CD20 B-cell antigen, which is expressed on the surface of B-lymphocytes, plasma cells, and certain B-cell lymphomas.

 

By binding to CD20, rituximab promotes apoptosis through transmembrane signaling and enhances antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) as well as complement-dependent cytotoxicity (CDC). Rituximab is widely used in the treatment of various B-cell malignancies, including B-cell lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). It can be used alone or in combination with chemotherapy.

 

Adverse effects include infusion-related reactions such as chills, fever, urticaria, rashes, dyspnea, and hypotension. To mitigate these, pretreatment with antihistamines and corticosteroids is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD20: Rituximab is not a polyclonal antibody. Polyclonal antibodies are derived from multiple B-cell clones and bind to various epitopes on the antigen. Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody, meaning it is derived from a single clone and binds specifically to one epitope on the CD20 antigen.

 

Option B. Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD50: Rituximab does not act against CD50, nor is it a polyclonal antibody. CD50 (ICAM-3) is involved in T-cell activation and leukocyte adhesion, not in B-cell lymphomas or chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

Option D. Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD50: Rituximab specifically targets CD20, not CD50. CD50 is associated with T-cell interactions, while rituximab is involved in targeting B-cell antigens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20 on B-cells, used in treating B-cell lymphomas and chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

questions.text: Identify the clinical diagnosis: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plexiform neurofibromatosis

 

Plexiform neurofibroma is seen in patients with NF1 commonly in the craniomaxillofacial region. Malignant transformation to MPNST (Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor) occurs in 3-16% patients and is the cause of mortality.

 

The mass typically appears as a "bag of worms" due to the involvement of multiple nerve branches.

 

Treatment is mainly surgical resection of the tumor

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve palsy: This condition typically presents with asymmetrical facial movement and weakness but does not cause mass-like growths.

 

Option B. Masticator space abscess: Characterized by swelling and pain, usually due to an infection, which would not cause the extensive, benign proliferative growth seen in the image.

 

Option D. Fibrous dysplasia: While it can cause bone deformity and asymmetry, it does not manifest as a soft, extensive mass typically seen in neurofibromatosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plexiform neurofibromatosis should be suspected in patients with extensive, soft, non-tender, and irregularly contoured masses along nerve pathways, particularly in those known to have or suspected of having NF1. Surgical resection can be considered for symptomatic relief or cosmetic reasons, though complete removal is often challenging due to the nature of the growth

choices.text: 3 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets, taken OD
IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets
2 iron and folic acid tablets OD + IV iron sucrose

questions.text: A pregnant woman presenting at less than 34 weeks of gestation displays signs of mild to moderate anemia. Under the "Anemia Mukh Bharat" initiative, which therapeutic approach would be the most appropriate? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets

 

The best treatment among the given options is IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets.

 

Severity of Anemia according to Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign,

 

  • Mild – 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate – 7-9 g%
  • Severe – <7 g %

 

Testing and treating Mild and Moderate Anemia:

 

  • If mild anemia OR moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron and folic acid
  • If patient presents late in pregnancy or is unable to tolerate oral iron: Parenteral iron – IV Iron sucrose or Ferric carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe anemia:

 

  • Hb < 7g%: Parenteral iron – IV Iron sucrose or Ferric carboxymaltose (FeCM).
  • If patient presents late in the third trimester with severe anemia or Hb is less than 5 g%: ADMIT

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anemia Mukt Bharat (2018)

 

Aim: Reduce anemia by 3% per year

 

6 x 6 x 6 strategy

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from the nose, nasal obstruction and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination and given histopathological image what would be the diagnosis of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidiosis

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by the aquatic organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It primarily affects mucous membranes, especially in the nasal passages but also the eyes, ears, and occasionally other areas. Patients typically present with polypoidal masses in the nasal area that can cause bleeding, nasal obstruction, and respiratory difficulty. It is commonly associated with exposure to stagnant water.

Histopathology: Characteristic findings include large, thick-walled sporangia containing numerous endospores, as observed in the provided histopathological image.

Other Options: 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma

Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that commonly appears on sun-exposed areas but can occasionally occur near the nasal region. It typically presents as a nodular lesion with a pearly edge and may have telangiectasias but lacks the distinct histopathology of sporangia with endospores.

Histopathology: Microscopically, it shows nests of basaloid cells with palisading nuclei at the periphery.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the respiratory tract. It leads to the formation of hard, sclerotic nodules and masses mainly in the nasal passages.

Histopathology: It is characterized by the presence of Mikulicz cells, which are large foam cells containing the bacteria, and a background of chronic inflammatory cells.

Option D. Lupus Vulgaris

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting typically on the skin with reddish-brown nodules and plaques that can ulcerate over time. It rarely affects the nasal area directly unless there is disseminated cutaneous involvement.

Histopathology: Shows granulomatous inflammation with caseating necrosis typical of tuberculosis.

Educational Objective:

Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients with nasal masses who have a history of contact with stagnant water bodies, presenting with the characteristic polypoidal mass and sporangia on histopathology.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy complains of cough and throat pain. On examination of the oral cavity, a white pseudomembrane was visualized. A swab was taken from it and stained as given in the image below. What is the procedure for the following staining? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Albert's stain- I
  2. Acid alcohol
  3. Gram's iodine
  4. Safranin
  5. Methylene blue
  6. Crystal violet
  7. Carbol fuschin
  8. Acetone
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6, 3, 8, 4

 

The image shows Gram's stain of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae are gram +ve rod shaped bacteria, Club shaped, non-capsulated, non sporing, non-motile,. Also known as Kleb’s-Loeffler Bacillus.

 

The Gram staining process includes four basic steps, including:

 

  1. Applying a primary stain (crystal violet). Option 6
  2. Adding a mordant (Gram’s iodine). Option 3
  3. Rapid decolorization with ethanol, acetone or a mixture of both. Option 8
  4. Counterstaining with safranin. Option 4

 

On microscopy –

 

  • Chinese letter arrangement, V or L shaped
  • Forms granules (metachromatic granules) which are the store house of energy.
  • Alberts’s stain, Loeffler’s methylene blue stain and Ponder’s stain shows metachromatic granules formed in the polar regions. Appears green in Alberts’s stain along with bluish black metachromatic granules at the poles.
    • Albert's I solution - Toluidine blue, Malachite green.
    • Albert's II solution - iodine and potassium iodide.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct Gram staining procedure for identifying Corynebacterium diphtheriae includes the steps of applying crystal violet, adding Gram's iodine, decolorizing with acetone, and counterstaining with safranin.

choices.text: Level 5 - Base of skull to cricoid

questions.text: The correct pair of lymph node level in the neck and anatomical boundaries amongst the following are? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Level 6 - Hyoid to clavicle

 

Explanation:

 

The correct pair of lymph nodes and levels among the following options are level 6- Hyoid to clavicle.

 

Level 6 lymph nodes are the anterior or central compartment nodes. They span from the hyoid bone (superiorly) to the sternum/clavicle (inferiorly), and from the carotid arteries laterally. This group includes pretracheal, paratracheal, and precricoid (Delphian) nodes. These nodes often come into consideration in thyroid cancers and some laryngeal and hypopharyngeal malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Level 3 - Cricoid to clavicle: This is incorrect. Level 3 lymph nodes are located in the middle jugular region, and their anatomical boundaries are the lower border of the hyoid bone (superiorly) and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (inferiorly). They are situated along the middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

 

Option B. Level 4 - Hyoid to cricoid: This is also incorrect. Level 4 lymph nodes are the lower jugular nodes, and their anatomical boundaries are the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (superiorly) and the clavicle (inferiorly). These nodes are situated along the inferior third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

 

Option C. Level 5 - Base of skull to cricoid: This is not correct. Level 5 lymph nodes are located in the posterior triangle of the neck, which is bound by the sternocleidomastoid muscle (anteriorly), the trapezius muscle (posteriorly), and the clavicle (inferiorly). Level 5 is further divided into Level 5A (located above the cricoid) and Level 5B (located below the cricoid to the clavicle). So, Level 5 spans from the base of the skull to the clavicle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymph node level in the neck and their anatomical boundaries -

 

To aid in the description and localization of lymph nodes, especially in cancer treatment and surgery, they have been categorized into specific levels. Each level is defined by anatomical landmarks.

choices.text: Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver tissue
Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis
White areas represent central hepatocytes

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis and ascites presented to you. The gross appearance of his liver is as shown below. Which among the following is true about it? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

The above picture shows centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis. The cut liver section, in which major blood vessels are visible, is notable for a variegated, mottled, red appearance (nutmeg liver) seen in right heart failure. The dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver which resembles the cut section of nutmeg. This occurs as a result of hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

 

The liver derives its blood supply from the portal venous system and the hepatic artery. The portal triad constitutes:

 

  • Branches of the hepatic artery
  • Portal vein
  • Bile duct

 

The blood from the portal vein and the hepatic artery flow through the intervening sinusoids and drains into the central vein. The central veins from adjacent lobules form interlobular veins, which then unite as hepatic veins and finally drain into the inferior vena cava.

 

The hepatic lobule is divided into three zones:

 

  • Zone 1 is the periportal area
  • Zone 2 is the Intermediate zone
  • Zone 3 is the area closest to the central vein

 

Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver. Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, known as nutmeg liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis: This is incorrect because the dark areas are where necrosis has occurred due to congestion, not viable tissue.

 

Option C. White areas represent central hepatocytes: The white areas represent periportal zones, which are generally healthier and not central hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Dark areas represent peri-portal hepatocytes: The dark areas actually represent the centrilobular regions where necrosis has occurred, not the periportal hepatocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nutmeg liver is characterized by a mottled appearance, where dark areas represent necrosis due to chronic passive congestion, and white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1665

choices.text: 70% amorphous 30% crystalline
70% crystalline 30% amorphous
Only 70% amorphous
D Other name of NPH insulin

questions.text: Composition of Lente insulin is? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 70% crystalline 30% amorphous

 

Lente insulin has two components in it:

 

  • Ultralente insulin, which is water insoluble insulin zinc suspension with large crystalline particles (70%), it has a long half-life.
  • Semilente insulin, which is amorphous, has smaller particles and is short acting. (30%)
  • These two components are mixed in this 7:3 ratio, making Lente insulin intermediate acting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70% amorphous 30% crystalline: This is incorrect as the amorphous part makes up only 30% of the composition in Lente insulin.

 

Option C. Only 70% amorphous: This is incorrect because Lente insulin is a mixture of both crystalline and amorphous components, not just one type.

 

Option D. Other name of NPH insulin: This is incorrect. Lente insulin and NPH (Neutral Protamine Hagedorn) insulin are different formulations. NPH insulin is an intermediate-acting insulin that is a suspension of insulin with protamine and zinc, which prolongs its action, but it is not referred to as Lente insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lente insulin is composed of 70% crystalline (long-acting) and 30% amorphous (short-acting) insulin, making it an intermediate-acting insulin formulation.

questions.text: You're a clinician in a busy urban sexual health clinic, and it's been a hectic day with multiple patients presenting with sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The STI treatment kits are color-coded for efficient management, but the new nurse seems a bit overwhelmed with the options. You decide to guide her. Based on the clinical presentation, which color-coded STI kit would you suggest for the following symptoms? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

A. Lower abdominal pain:

 

  • Correct Kit: Yellow, Kit 6, which includes Cefixime, Metronidazole, and Doxycycline, specifically designed to manage symptoms like lower abdominal pain, which can be associated with pelvic inflammatory disease or other related conditions.

 

B. Urethral discharge:

 

  • Correct Kit: Grey, Kit 1, which contains Azithromycin and Cefixime. This kit is ideal for treating symptoms like urethral discharge, which can indicate infections such as gonorrhea or chlamydia.

 

C. Non-herpetic genital ulcer:

 

  • Correct Kit: White, Kit 3, equipped with Azithromycin and Penicillin, suitable for treating non-herpetic genital ulcers, often caused by syphilis or chancroid.

 

D. Vaginal discharge:

 

  • Correct Kit: Green, Kit 2, which contains Secnidazole and Fluconazole, tailored for treating vaginal discharge that could be due to bacterial vaginosis or yeast infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The National Aids Control Organization (NACO has provided color-coded kits for the syndromic management of sexually transmitted diseases:

questions.text: Identify the cells marked in the given image? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphocyte- 1, Monocyte-4, Eosinophil-2, Basophil-3, Neutrophil -5

 

 

A peripheral blood smear shows RBCs, WBCs (granulocytes and agranulocytes), and platelets.

 

1. Lymphocyte : Lymphocytes are slightly larger than red blood cells (RBCs) and have a large, dense nucleus with little cytoplasm and no granules.

 

4. Monocyte : Monocytes are the largest WBCs with a kidney-shaped nucleus and abundant cytoplasm without granules.

 

2. Eosinophil : Eosinophils have bilobed nuclei (spectacle-shaped) with large, brick-red (eosinophilic) granules in the cytoplasm.

 

3. Basophil : Basophils have large bluish granules that obscure the nucleus, which is often difficult to see due to the dense granulation.

 

5. Neutrophil : Neutrophils typically have a multi-lobed (3-5 lobes) nucleus and fine bluish granules in the cytoplasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulocytes:

 

  • Neutrophil - 3 to 5 lobed nucleus with small, bluish granules in the cytoplasm
  • Eosinophil - Binucleate/spectacle shaped nuclei with brick-red granules in the cytoplasm
  • Basophil- Large bluish granules in the cytoplasm which obscure the nucleus.

 

Agranulocytes:

 

  • Lymphocytes- size just larger than an BC. No granules, no nucleoli present.
  • Monocytes - largest cells with a kidney-shaped nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have polysaccharide vaccine?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are typically made from the polysaccharide capsule that surrounds certain bacteria. These vaccines are designed to protect against bacterial infections by inducing immunity against the polysaccharide antigens present in the capsule.

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant vaccine that uses a portion of the hepatitis B virus (HBsAg - hepatitis B surface antigen) produced in yeast cells. This vaccine does not involve a polysaccharide component as the hepatitis B virus does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal: The pneumococcal vaccine is available in both polysaccharide (PPSV23) and conjugate forms (PCV13), targeting the polysaccharide capsule of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option B. Meningococcal: Meningococcal vaccines also include polysaccharide (MPSV4) and conjugate forms (MCV4), aimed at the polysaccharide capsule of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Option C. H. influenzae: The Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is a conjugate vaccine that includes the polysaccharide antigen from the bacterial capsule conjugated to a protein carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine, as it targets a virus that does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

choices.text: Painless vaginal bleeding
Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding

questions.text: Antepartum hemorrhage due to abruption shows all except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Painless vaginal bleeding

 

Explanation:

 

  • Painless vaginal bleeding is not a feature of abruption of the placenta. It is a characteristic feature of placenta previa.
  • Patients with placental abruption present with sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions.
  • Abruptio placenta is the partial or total separation of a normally implanted placenta before delivery, leading to bleeding and other complications.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Uterine tenderness: This is a common feature of placental abruption due to the separation of the placenta from the uterine wall.

 

Option B. Frequent contractions: Increased frequency of uterine contractions is associated with placental abruption.

 

Option D. Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding: Vaginal bleeding of varying degrees, from mild to severe, is typically seen in placental abruption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placental abruption presents with sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions, but not with painless vaginal bleeding, which is characteristic of placenta previa.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg1944,  Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 297

questions.text: Structure lies in the floor of inferior horn of lateral ventricle all except (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tail of caudate nucleus

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn, not the floor.

 

Roof of Inferior horn - Tapetum (part of the corpus callosum), medial part of tail of the Caudate Nucleus and Striate Terminus

 

Floor of Inferior horn – Fimbria, hippocampus, collateral sulcus and collateral eminence.

 

Other Options:

 

The inferior horn of the lateral ventricle is a part of the brain located in the temporal lobe. Structures found in the floor of the inferior horn include the hippocampus, fimbria, and collateral eminence.

 

Option A. Collateral eminence: This is a ridge in the floor of the inferior horn formed by the collateral sulcus.

 

Option B. Hippocampus: A crucial structure for memory conversion, located in the floor of the inferior horn.

 

Option C. Fimbria: A bundle of nerve fibers on the hippocampus that forms part of the floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle, not in the floor.

questions.text: Match the following cancers with their corresponding criteria for the minimum number of lymph nodes required for pathological staging: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

The minimum number of lymph nodes required for accurate staging are 16 for stomach carcinoma, 12 for colon carcinoma, 6 for gall bladder carcinoma, and 10 for breast carcinoma.

questions.text: The following test is positive for identification of: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

 

The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans.

 

Germ tube test is a screening test for the presumptive identification of Candida albicans. Candida dubliniensis can also form germ tubes and Candida tropicalis can produce pseudohyphae that closely resemble germ tubes.

 

Germ tube formation was first reported by Reynolds and Braude and hence the germ tube test is also known as Reynolds-Braude phenomenon.

 

Buds and pseudo-hyphae can be distinguished from germ tubes by the constricted attachment at the point of origin. Germ tubes don’t show constriction at the point of origin.

 

Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis produce short, slender, tube-like structures called germ tubes.

 

The formation of germ tubes is associated with increased synthesis of protein and ribonucleic acid. Various media like fetal bovine serum may be used as a substitute for human pooled serum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candida glabrata: Candida glabrata does not produce germ tubes. It forms small, round yeast cells.

 

Option C. Candida parapsilosis: Candida parapsilosis does not produce germ tubes. It forms pseudohyphae and yeast cells.

 

Option D. Candida tropicalis: Candida tropicalis can produce pseudohyphae that resemble germ tubes, but they show constriction at the point of origin. This is a distinguishing feature from the true germ tubes of Candida albicans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The germ tube test is used for the presumptive identification of Candida albicans. It detects the formation of germ tubes, which are characteristic of Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis but not other Candida species. Germ tubes are short, slender, tube-like structures without constriction at their point of origin, differentiating them from pseudohyphae.

questions.text: What is the bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 100%

 

Bioavailability of an administered drug is the fraction of that drug that reaches unchanged into systemic circulation. It depends upon 2 factors:

 

  • Absorption of the drug from the site of application
  • First pass metabolism

 

The bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously (I.V) is 100% because it is neither subjected to the first-pass metabolism as in oral route nor does it depend on local factors that affect absorption as in subcutaneous, intramuscular, or transdermal. In IV route, the drug is directly delivered to the systemic circulation and hence has the maximum availability for action at the intended site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously is 100% because the drug is directly delivered into the systemic circulation without any loss due to absorption barriers or first-pass metabolism.

questions.text:
Examine the list of features given: [INICET MAY 2024]

 

  1. Delayed skin pinch
  2. Lethargy
  3. Thirst
  4. Sunken eyes
  5. Reduced Urine output

 

The features of some dehydration include:
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 3, 4

 

According to the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, dehydration is categorized into three types: no dehydration, some dehydration, and severe dehydration.

 

  • Some Dehydration: This condition is diagnosed when there are at least two of the following four signs: thirst, sunken eyes, delayed skin pinch (skin pinch goes back slowly), and restlessness or irritability. These signs indicate a moderate level of dehydration where the body is starting to show physical symptoms, but it has not yet progressed to a severe state.
  • In the question:
    • Delayed skin pinch (option 1) is one of the signs.
    • Thirst (option 3) is another sign.
    • Sunken eyes (option 4) is also a recognized sign of some dehydration.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option B, which includes all the relevant features (1, 3, and 4).

 

Other Options:

 

2: Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, not some dehydration, which makes this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • According to the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, dehydration is categorized into three levels based on specific signs and symptoms:

choices.text: Block sodium channels
Block potassium channels
Block calcium channels
Block chloride channels

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Block sodium channels

 

  • Mechanism: Local anesthetics primarily act by blocking the sodium channels bound to the membrane of the nerve, thus inhibiting sodium influx into the nerve and avoiding depolarization of the nerve.
  • States of Sodium Channels: The voltage-gated sodium channels exist in three states:
    • Resting (non-conducting)
    • Open (conducting)
    • Inactivated (non-conducting)
  • Affinity: Local anesthetics have maximum affinity for the sodium channels in the inactivated state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Block potassium channels:

Blocking potassium channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Potassium channels are more involved in the repolarization phase of the action potential.

 

Option C. Block calcium channels:

Blocking calcium channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Calcium channels are more involved in neurotransmitter release at synapses.

 

Option D. Block chloride channels:

Blocking chloride channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Chloride channels are typically associated with inhibitory neurotransmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Local anesthetics work by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, which prevents the influx of sodium ions into nerve cells, thereby inhibiting nerve depolarization and the propagation of action potentials.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 871

questions.text:
Calculate the ECF volume in a volunteer in whom 10 gm of mannitol was injected in venous blood. At equilibrium urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was 65 mg/100 ml?

In a volunteer, 10 grams of mannitol was injected into the venous blood. At equilibrium, the urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was measured at 65 mg/100 ml. Calculate the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume based on this information. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 14L

 

ECF volume of the above volunteer is calculated to be 14 L.

 

Mannitol is a marker of ECF volume as it does not cross the cell membrane and remains in the ECF.

 

The ECF volume can be calculated using the formula:

 

 

Where,

 

  • V = ECF volume
  • Amount injected = 10 gm
  • Amount of mannitol excreted = 10% of 10 gm = 1gm

  • Plasma concentration of mannitol = 65 mg/100mL = 0.65 gm/L

     

Calculation:

 

ECF Volume = (10-1) /0.65 = 13.8 L = approximately 14 L

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extracellular fluid (ECF) volume can be calculated by using the dilution principle, taking into account the amount of marker substance injected, the amount excreted, and the plasma concentration of the marker.

choices.text: When he complains of decrease in vision

questions.text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a dilated fundus examination for him? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediately

 

Immediate dilated fundus examination is recommended for individuals diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, as early detection of diabetic retinopathy is crucial for preventing vision loss. Screening at diagnosis is essential because diabetic retinopathy can be asymptomatic in its early stages, yet still pose a risk of significant damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Before his 50th birthday: While this is within five years of diagnosis, immediate examination is preferred for immediate intervention and management.

 

Option C. After his 50th birthday: Delaying the examination could lead to unnoticed progression of diabetic retinopathy and potentially irreversible damage.

 

Option D. When he complains of decrease in vision: Waiting for symptoms such as decreased vision can result in delayed diagnosis of diabetic retinopathy, at which point some damage may be irreversible.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in low insulin-glucagon ratio?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glycogen storage

 

A low insulin: glucagon ratio (IGR) stimulates mobilization of stored nutrients, increases glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, ketogenesis and promotes the breakdown of adipose tissue into free fatty acids and glycerol.

 

Conversely, glycogen storage is not promoted during a low insulin-glucagon ratio. Glycogen storage occurs in a high insulin state, where insulin promotes the uptake and storage of glucose as glycogen in liver and muscle tissues.

 

Other Options :

 

The processes influenced by a low IGR include:

 

Option A. Glycogen Breakdown (Glycogenolysis): The breakdown of glycogen into glucose is stimulated to provide immediate energy.

 

Option B. Ketogenesis: The production of ketone bodies from fatty acids occurs in the liver as an alternative energy source, particularly for the brain during prolonged fasting.

 

Option D. Gluconeogenesis: The synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors such as lactate, glycerol, and amino acids is enhanced to maintain blood glucose levels.

 

Educational Objective :

 

A low insulin-glucagon ratio stimulates the mobilization of energy stores by promoting glycogen breakdown, ketogenesis, and gluconeogenesis, while it inhibits glycogen storage.

choices.text: Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text:
Assertion: Decompression surgery is needed with progressive neurological difficulty in Pott’s spine. (AIIMS May 2019)

 

Reason: Even after completion of ATT, there can be neurological abnormalities.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion

 

  • When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT.
  • Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • The spine is the most common site of skeletal tuberculosis, accounting for 50% of cases followed by hip (15%) and knee (10%).
  • Any level of the spine may be involved, the lower thoracic region being the most common followed by lumbar > upper dorsal > cervical > sacral region.
  • Types:

 

 

  • Clinical features: Pain, stiffness, cold abscess formation, paraplegia, deformity, fever, weight loss.
  • Imaging:
    1. Plain radiograph:
      • Reduction of disc space
      • Vertebral body destruction
      • Paravertebral abscess
      • Widening of mediastinum
    2. CT scan: 
      • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
    3. MRI: 
      • It is the investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
      • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.
    4. Biopsy: 
      • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.
  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:
    • Stage 1: Patient has no neural complaint clinician elicits increased reflexes.
    • Stage 2: Patient has weakness but can walk with support.
    • Stage 3: Patient is non-ambulatory or has sensory loss <50%.
    • Stage 4: Patient has bowel/bladder involvement or sensory loss >50%.
  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India.
    • Patient is treated by antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on nonoperative management but if indications of surgery exist  then he needs to be operated.
  • Stage-wise Treatment:

 

 

  • ATT: 
    • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
    • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB, the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
  • Indications of surgery in any disease of spine:
    1. Bowel bladder involvement.
    2. Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
    3. No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks or
    4. Surgical options for most of the cases are: anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
    5. Hong Kong operation is also carried out for Pott’s spine.
    6. Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed).

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

Note:

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.

 

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT.
  • Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.

choices.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain.
Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is scheduled for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

 

Laparoscopic surgeries have become popular as they result in lesser post-operative pain, are cosmetically better, and result in an earlier return to normal physiological function (Options A, B, and C). Patients are discharged from the hospital earlier, with a lower incidence of complications, as compared to open surgeries. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer, as it is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery.

 

This statement is incorrect. Laparoscopic surgery is associated with shorter hospital stays compared to traditional open surgery. Patients typically spend less time in the hospital and recover faster, which is one of the key advantages of this approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain: Smaller incisions and less tissue trauma typically result in less post-operative pain compared to traditional open surgery.

 

Option B. Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions: This is an advantage of laparoscopic surgery. The smaller incisions are not only cosmetically appealing but also result in reduced scarring and a lower risk of wound infections.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function: Patients often recover more quickly and can resume their normal activities sooner due to the minimally invasive nature of the procedure.

choices.text: Information is not enough for the diagnosis

questions.text: An elderly male patient who received a kidney transplant a decade ago is presently under immunosuppressive treatment. He reports experiencing a persistent cough and shortness of breath over the past week. Microscopic examination of his sputum reveals the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. What is the probable diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Invasive candidiasis

 

  • The presented clinical scenario, coupled with the microscopy revealing gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae, strongly indicates the presence of invasive candidiasis.
  • Candida albicans has a unique ability to transform frequently between three phenotypic forms in the tissue: yeast, pseudohyphae, true hyphae. This property helps it to evade host defense system.
  • Invasive candidiasis results from hematogenous or local spread of the fungi.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor shows, broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching.

 

Option B. Aspergillus shows septate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Invasive candidiasis is characterized by the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae in tissue or clinical specimens, especially in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to you with neuropathy in his bilateral lower limbs and a positive Romberg sign. He has a history of gastrectomy for stomach cancer. He is likely deficient in which of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

The case presents a classic scenario of Vitamin B12 deficiency due to gastrectomy. When a patient undergoes gastric surgery, there is a decrease in parietal cell mass, which leads to reduced secretion of both hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor. Intrinsic factor is crucial for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the terminal ileum.

 

Its deficiency leads to malabsorption of vitamin B12, resulting in neurological manifestations and Haematological Manifestations:

 

 Neurological Manifestations:

 

  • Neuropathy in bilateral lower limbs: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to demyelination of the dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts, resulting in sensory loss and weakness.
  • Positive Romberg sign: This indicates impaired proprioception, which is a hallmark of subacute combined degeneration (SCD) of the spinal cord.
  • Other neurological symptoms: Tingling, numbness, gait disturbances, and even cognitive impairment.

 

Hematological Manifestations:

 

  • Megaloblastic anemia: Due to impaired DNA synthesis, leading to macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral smear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine deficiency

 

  • Incorrect because thiamine absorption occurs in the duodenum and is not dependent on intrinsic factor
  • Does not typically present with peripheral neuropathy as the primary manifestation

 

Option B. Folate deficiency

 

  • Incorrect because folate absorption is not dependent on intrinsic factor
  • While it can cause megaloblastic anemia, it does not cause neurological manifestations

 

Option D. Transferrin deficiency

 

  • Incorrect because transferrin is related to iron transport and is not primarily affected by gastrectomy
  • Does not cause neurological manifestations

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Post-gastrectomy patients are at high risk for Vitamin B12 deficiency due to lack of intrinsic factor production, leading to neurological manifestations like peripheral neuropathy, positive Romberg sign and megaloblastic anemia. Lifelong vitamin B12 supplementation is essential in such patients to prevent neurological and hematological complications.

 

 

Causes of B12 Deficiency

 

  1. Vegans
  2. At stomach level - Elderly/ gastrectomy / Pernicious anemia
  3. At pancreas level - Pancreatitis, hypofunctioning pancreas
  4.  At intestine level - Bacterial overgrowth syndrome, diverticulosis.
  5. At ileum level - Malabsorption disorders, GIT TB, Crohn's disease, fish tapeworm
  6. ↓ intake
  7. ↓ absorption - ↓ intrinsic factor – pernicious anemia
  8. ↑ requirement - Children, pregnancy, lactation

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in damage control surgery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vascular anastomosis

 

Damage control surgery (DCS) is a staged approach that involves minimal intervention to stabilize the patient and perform definitive surgery later. The focus of DCS is on hemorrhage control, resuscitation, and limiting contamination. It includes an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and closure of the abdomen to blunt the physiologic response to prolonged shock and massive hemorrhage. After the initial steps of DCS, definitive surgery involving vascular anastomosis may be performed.

 

Vascular anastomosis is not typically included in damage control surgery.

 

Vascular anastomosis, is generally not performed during the initial phase of damage control surgery. Damage control surgery prioritizes addressing life-threatening injuries and stabilizing the patient. Complex procedures like vascular anastomosis are typically deferred to later, definitive surgery, after the patient's condition has been stabilized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemorrhage control: Hemorrhage control is a critical component of damage control surgery. The primary goal of damage control surgery is to address life-threatening bleeding and stop any ongoing hemorrhage. Surgeons often use various techniques, such as packing wounds or applying temporary closures, to achieve hemorrhage control during the initial phase of damage control surgery.

 

Option B. Resuscitation: Resuscitation is a key aspect of damage control surgery. Patients who require damage control surgery are often in a state of shock due to significant blood loss and trauma. Resuscitation involves stabilizing the patient's condition by providing fluids, blood products, and other supportive measures to restore blood volume and vital organ function. It is usually done in ICU after hemorrhage is stopped.

 

Option C. Decontamination: Decontamination may be necessary in specific situations, such as chemical or biological contamination, gross spillage into peritoneum or dirty wounds.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

vascular anastomosis (option D) is not a standard part of damage control surgery, while the other options (A, B, and C) are relevant components of this surgical approach.

questions.text: The patient, aged 60, shows a lesion as depicted in the image below. Additionally, he reports that he felt a spider crawling in the area of the lesion when he woke up. What is the most probable diagnosis based on this information? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes zoster infection

 

The above image shows confluent, red, vesicular lesions in a single dermatome along with spider crawling sensation (paraesthesia) is highly suggestive of Herpes zoster infection.

 

  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Irritant contact dermatitis

 

It typically presents with erythema and scaling and can include blistering, but it is not usually unilateral or confined to a dermatomal pattern as seen in the image.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis

 

This causes an itchy, red rash and may lead to blisters. The distribution is typically at the site of contact with the allergen and not dermatomal.

 

Option D. Herpes Simplex infection: It presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, usually around the lips or genital region as shown in the image below. It does not follow a dermatomal pattern.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a 60-year-old patient presenting with a unilateral vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution, the most likely diagnosis is herpes zoster infection.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

questions.text: In a village, the residents find a new groundwater source. After intake of water from this source many villagers presented with nausea, vomiting, dark bloody stools, conjunctivitis, and a burning sensation in the throat and stomach. Which poisoning do you suspect in this case? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Arsenic

 

The given clinical scenario points towards arsenic poisoning

 

Causes of arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning occurs most often in major areas of agriculture and industrialization. It occurs through contaminated groundwater, air, soil or food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium permanganate: Typically causes caustic injuries, including severe mucosal burns upon ingestion, but not the full range of symptoms described.

 

Option C. Thallium: Causes symptoms such as gastrointestinal distress, neurological symptoms, and hair loss, but does not match the full clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning causes anemia, abdominal pain, neurological symptoms, and kidney damage, but does not match the described symptoms of conjunctivitis and burning sensation in the throat and stomach.

 

Educational Objective:
